elements.content: The parent compound 1,3-dithiane (L1) was reacted with CuI providing the 1D coordination polymer [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] n (CP1), an isostructural compound [{Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] n (CP2) was isolated upon treatment of CuBr with L1. In contrast, treatment of L1 with CuCl results in the formation of 2D polymeric [{Cu­(μ2-Cl)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)] n (CP3), in which each sulfur atom acts as a 4-electron donor. The 1D compounds [{Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n (CP7, X = Br, and CP8, X = Cl) resulting from treatment of 2-methyl-1,3 dithiane (L2) with CuBr and CuCl are isostructural with their CuI homologue [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n (CP5), reported previously. Using CuCN, a 2D CP of composition [{Cu­(μ2-CN)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n (CP9) has been isolated. Complexation of 2-isobutyl-1,3-dithiane (L3) on CuI generates a 2D material [{Cu3(μ3-I)­(μ2-I)2(μ2-L3)2}] n (CP10), incorporating the usual trinuclear μ3-I-capped Cu clusters as SBUs, whereas 2D-polymeric compounds [{Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu}­(μ2-L3)2] n (CP11) and [{Cu­(μ2-Cl)2Cu}­(μ2-L3)2] n (CP12) were obtained with CuBr and CuCl. Treatment of 2-Me3Si-1,3-dithiane (L4) with CuX yields the series [{Cu2(μ4-X)­(μ2-X)}­(μ2-L4)] n (CP13–CP15). With 2-phenyl-1,3-dithiane (L5), the outcome of the reaction with CuI depends on the reaction conditions. Reaction with CuI in MeCN provides a 1D ribbon [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(MeCN)2(μ2-L5)2] n (CP16), whereas treatment of CuI with L5 in hot EtCN yields 2D-polymeric­[{Cu3(μ3-I)­(μ2-I)2(μ2-L5)2}] n (CP17). A reversible phase transition from triclinic P1̅ to monoclinic P21/m is observed when recording the structure of CP16 at five different temperatures in the 100–300 K range. Ligand L6 containing a ferrocenyl function at the 2-position was also probed as organometallic dithioether ligand. Reaction of L6 with 1 equiv of CuI produces the 0D dinuclear complex [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(η1-L6)2(MeCN)2] (D1), whereas treatment with 2 equiv of CuI affords the novel 1D CP [{Cu­(μ3-I)2Cu}­(μ-L6)] n (CP18), in which both S atoms of one L6 molecule span two copper centers of the infinite (CuI) n ribbon. Some selected results of thermal analyses and luminescence measurements are also presented.

elements.content:
A complete series of Cu­(I) coordination polymers with varying dimensionalities and incorporating (CuX) n cluster as SBUs was prepared from 2-substituted 1,3-dithianes

Introduction

Polydentate macrocyclic thiacrown ether ligands are able to coordinate a wide range of transition metal complexes both in endocyclic and in exocyclic manner, yielding discrete molecular complexes. They have also been used as assembling ligands to construct 1D and 2D coordination polymers and 3D MOFs. The less flexible six-membered dithiaheterocycle 1,3-dithiane (L1) (also named 1,3-dithiacyclohexane) has also been used in the past as a mono- and bidentate ligand to coordinate to a series of early and late transition metal complexes. Crystallographically characterized examples include mono- and dinuclear compounds [(C6H6)­Cr­(CO)2(κ1-L1)], [Fe­(CO)4(κ1-L1)], [(C5H5)­Ru­(PPh3)2(κ1-L1)]­[CF3SO3], [(C5Me5)­IrCl2(κ1-L1)], and [{(C5Me5)­IrCl2}2(μ2-L1)], as well as polynuclear clusters such as [(μ2-H)2Ru3(CO)8Cl­(μ3-η3-L1)] and [H4Ru4(CO)10(μ2-L1)]. The propensity of 1,3-dithiane to act even as a μ2-S,S 4-electron donor has been evidenced for [Os6CO16(μ2-L1)], where L1 is bridging across an Os–Os edge via one of the sulfur atoms. The use of 1,3-dithiane as assembling ligand for the construction of coordination polymers (CPs) has been first demonstrated by the crystallographic characterization of 1D polymeric 1,3-dithianedimercury­(I) dinitrate. Several CPs have been built up by treatment of 1,3-dithiane with AgNO3, AgBF4, and AgPF6, respectively. More recently, Keller and Knaust reacted [Cu­(MeCN)4]­BF4 with L1 and obtained four coordination networks depending on the metal-to-ligand ratio and solvent conditions used.

elements.content: We have previously shown that the isomeric 1,2-dithiane heterocycle is formed upon treatment of 1,4-butanedithiol in the presence of CuI, yielding the luminescent 1D material [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(1,2-dithiane)2] n featuring rhomboid Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu clusters, which are linked through the S atoms of six-membered 1,2-dithiane heterocycles. In contrast to [Cu­(MeCN)4]+ salts, CuI and CuBr readily form upon complexation with thioethers halide-bridged polynuclear aggregates, whose nuclearities and geometries are almost unpredictable. We and other research groups encountered after ligation of aliphatic and aromatic dithioethers RS­(CH2) n SR (n = 1–8) and RSCH2CCCH2SR a panoply of discrete molecular compounds, CPs, and MOFs of varying dimensionality incorporating as connecting nodes the Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu rhomboid, the tetranuclear closed-cubane Cu4I4 cluster, the prismane-shaped Cu6I6 cluster, and the fused octanuclear Cu8I8 cluster. Apart from the fascinating structural richness of these compounds, their photophysical properties, often associated with intense photoluminescence and luminescence thermochromism, intrigued us to investigate in detail the coordination chemistry of 1,3-dithiane (L1) and 2-substituted derivatives such as 2-methyl-1,3-dithiane (L2), 2-isobutyl-1,3-dithiane (L3), 2-Me3Si-1,3-dithiane (L4), 2-phenyl-1,3-dithiane (L5), and 2-ferrocenyl-1,3-dithiane (L6) vis-à-vis CuI, CuBr and CuCl. This study completes our recent investigation on the coordination of 2-methyl-1,3-dithiane (L2) on CuI where, depending on the reaction conditions, both topological isomers of composition [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n or the luminescent 3D material [{Cu8(μ3-I)8}­(μ2-L2)4] n , exhibiting an unprecedented octanuclear Cu8I8S8 SBU, have been prepared and structurally characterized. The chemical structures of the investigated ligands along with the dimensionalities and nuclearities of the secondary building units (SBUs) of the resulting CPs are shown in .

elements.content: In continuation of our previous work on the coordination chemistry of cyclic and acyclic dithioether ligands on CuX salts and to complete the series of ionic Cu­(I) networks obtained by Keller and Knaust by treatment of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­BF4 with 1,3-dithiane (L1), we reacted this heterocycle with CuI in a 1:1 ratio. After heating in EtCN, a colorless crystalline material of composition [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] n was obtained in over 90% yield ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and X-ray Diffraction Characterization of the CPs

Treatment of 1,3-Dithiane (L1) with CuX (X = I, Br, Cl)

In continuation of our previous work on the coordination chemistry of cyclic and acyclic dithioether ligands on CuX salts and to complete the series of ionic Cu(I) networks obtained by Keller and Knaust by treatment of [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 with 1,3-dithiane (L1), we reacted this heterocycle with CuI in a 1:1 ratio. After heating in EtCN, a colorless crystalline material of composition [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}(μ2-L1)2] n  was obtained in over 90% yield ().

elements.content: An X-ray diffraction study revealed formation of ribbon-like 1D coordination polymer, in which rhomboid Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu units are linked through bridging dithiane cycles using both S atom as donor sites ( and S1). Let us first compare the structural features of [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] with those of its 1D isomer [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(1,2-dithiane)2] n . This latter is assembled by rhomboid Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu clusters, which are linked through the S atoms of six-membered 1,2-dithiane heterocycles, thus generating an infinite ribbon. But in contrast to [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2], where the centrosymmetric Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu units are arranged roughly perpendicular with respect to the 1,3-dithiane cycles, those of [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(1,2-dithiane)2] n are approximately coplanar. Another striking difference concerns the Cu···Cu distances within the Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu rhomboids, which are far longer in the 1,3-dithiane isomer than in 1,2-dithiane one (2.8904(6) vs. 2.6843(18) Å).

This latter is assembled by rhomboid Cu(μ2-I)2Cu clusters, which are linked through the S atoms of six-membered 1,2-dithiane heterocycles, thus generating an infinite ribbon. But in contrast to [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}(μ2-L1)2], where the centrosymmetric Cu(μ2-I)2Cu units are arranged roughly perpendicular with respect to the 1,3-dithiane cycles, those of [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}(1,2-dithiane)2] n  are approximately coplanar. Another striking difference concerns the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances within the Cu(μ2-I)2Cu rhomboids, which are far longer in the 1,3-dithiane isomer than in 1,2-dithiane one (2.8904(6) vs. 2.6843(18) Å).

elements.content: The coordination mode of [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] is more reminiscent of that encountered in 1D CP [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}2{μ-PhS­(CH2)2SPh}2] n , displaying a Cu···Cu separation of 2.8058(11) Å. Other complexes exhibiting a rhomboidal Cu2I2 unit and weak Cu···Cu interactions close to the values of [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­{μ-PhS­(CH2)mSPh}2] n (m = 2,3,5) have been reported for the 3D CP [Cu2I2[16]­aneS4] n ([16]­aneS4 = 1,5,9,13-tetrathiacyclohexadecane) (2.8079(12) Å and dinuclear [{MeSi­(CH2SMe)3}­CuI]2 (2.862(2) Å).

Other complexes exhibiting a rhomboidal Cu2I2 unit and weak Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu interactions close to the values of [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}{μ-PhS(CH2)mSPh}2] n  (m = 2,3,5) have been reported for the 3D CP [Cu2I2[16]aneS4] n  ([16]aneS4 = 1,5,9,13-tetrathiacyclohexadecane) (2.8079(12) Å and dinuclear [{MeSi(CH2SMe)3}CuI]2 (2.862(2) Å).

elements.content: The homogeneity of the phase was ascertained by recording the PXRD spectrum (Figure S17). Previous studies from our group have shown that the CuI-to-ligand ratio may have a crucial impact on the architecture as well as on nuclearity within the (CuI) n clusters of the resulting network. For example, mixing CuI and PhS­(CH2)5SPh in a 2:1 ratio results in formation of [Cu4I4{μ-PhS­(CH2)5Ph}2] n in which cubane-like Cu4(μ3-I)4 cluster are linked by the bridging dithioether ligand giving rise to a 1D necklace structure. However, a 1D-chain with composition [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­{μ-PhS­(CH2)5SPh}2] n , incorporating rhomboid Cu2I2 units, is produced upon treatment of CuI with 1,5-bis­(phenylthio)­pentane in a 1:1 ratio. Therefore, we reacted 1,3-dithiane also with 2 equiv of CuI in MeCN solution. However, a comparison of the PXRD spectra (Figure S17) revealed that no other species is present in the precipitated colorless bulk material. Note also that, in this case and in contrast to L2 (see below), the order of addition of the reactants does not affect the outcome of the reaction.

For example, mixing CuI and PhS(CH2)5SPh in a 2:1 ratio results in formation of [Cu4I4{μ-PhS(CH2)5Ph}2] n  in which cubane-like Cu4(μ3-I)4 cluster are linked by the bridging dithioether ligand giving rise to a 1D necklace structure. Therefore, we reacted 1,3-dithiane also with 2 equiv of CuI in MeCN solution. However, a comparison of the PXRD spectra (Figure S17) revealed that no other species is present in the precipitated colorless bulk material. Note also that, in this case and in contrast to L2 (see below), the order of addition of the reactants does not affect the outcome of the reaction.

elements.content: We reacted L1 also with CuBr, under analogous conditions. Again a colorless, sparingly soluble material of composition [{Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] n CP2 was formed ( and Figure S2), crystallizing like [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] n in the orthorhombic space group Pnma. Compared with the latter, the Cu···Cu contact of 2.9143(3) Å is looser and matches well with that of 1D CP [{Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu}­(μ2-PhSCH2SPh)2] n (2.9192­(8) Å).
elements.clean_text: We reacted L1 also with CuBr, under analogous conditions. Again a colorless, sparingly soluble material of composition [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(μ2-L1)2] n  CP2 was formed ( and Figure S2), crystallizing like [{Cu(μ2-I)2Cu}(μ2-L1)2] n  in the orthorhombic space group Pnma. Compared with the latter, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu contact of 2.9143(3) Å is looser and matches well with that of 1D CP [{Cu(μ2-Br)2Cu}(μ2-PhSCH2SPh)2] n (2.9192(8) Å).

elements.content: View of the 1D ribbon of [{Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] n CP2. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): Cu···Cu# 2.9143(3), Cu–Br 2.4478(2), Cu–Br# 2.5088(2), Cu–S1 2.2989(3); Cu–S2 2.3009(3), Cu–Br–Cu# 72.011(6), S1–Cu–S2 105.170(11), S1–Cu–Br 112.192(9), S1–Cu–Br# 109.151(9), S2–Cu–Br 113.089(8), and S2–Cu–Br# 109.169(9).

Tan and Ang reported that L1 reacts readily with CuCl2 to form a paramagnetic species [CuCl2(L1)] undergoing spontaneously reduction to give finally [Cu2Cl2(L1)] according to elemental analysis and magnetic measurements. We repeated this experiment using CuCl2·2H2O as starting material and noticed also progressive discoloration of the initially green solution to yellowish with precipitation of a colorless powder, which was analyzed to have indeed a composition [Cu2Cl2(L1)]. Note that other reductions of CuCl2 to CuCl species in the presence of thioethers have been reported previously. In an alternative approach, we added a 2-fold amount of CuCl to a MeCN solution of L1, causing rapid precipitation of a microcrystalline solid in over 85% yield (). This latter was analyzed to have also a 2:1 Cu:L1 composition, different from the 1:1 Cu:L1 composition found for CP1 and CP2. By recrystallization of a sample from hot EtCN, small single-crystals crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21/c could be grown. Examination of the X-ray data of [{Cu­(μ2-Cl)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)] n (CP3) () reveals that the dimensionality of the network has changed to 2D. Like in CP1 and CP2, rhomboid Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu SBUs are present, but they are composed of two crystallographically distinct Cu atoms with Cu1···Cu2 separation of 2.809(2) Å. Apart from the dimensionality, the second salient feature concerns the bonding mode of the S atoms. Whereas in CP1 and CP2 all S atoms act as 2-electron donors, in CP3 both lone pairs of the S-donors are engaged in bonding as schematically shown in . The propensity of 1,3-dithiane to act as a μ2-S,S 4-electron donor has been previously evidenced for the cluster [Os6CO16(μ2-L1)], where L1 is bridging across an Os–Os edge via one of the sulfur atoms.

In an alternative approach, we added a 2-fold amount of CuCl to a MeCN solution of L1, causing rapid precipitation of a microcrystalline solid in over 85% yield (). This latter was analyzed to have also a 2:1 Cu:L1 composition, different from the 1:1 Cu:L1 composition found for CP1 and CP2. By recrystallization of a sample from hot EtCN, small single-crystals crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21/c could be grown. Examination of the X-ray data of [{Cu(μ2-Cl)2Cu}(μ2-L1)] n  (CP3) () reveals that the dimensionality of the network has changed to 2D. Like in CP1 and CP2, rhomboid Cu(μ2-X)2Cu SBUs are present, but they are composed of two crystallographically distinct Cu atoms with Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 separation of 2.809(2) Å. Apart from the dimensionality, the second salient feature concerns the bonding mode of the S atoms. Whereas in CP1 and CP2 all S atoms act as 2-electron donors, in CP3 both lone pairs of the S-donors are engaged in bonding as schematically shown in . The propensity of 1,3-dithiane to act as a μ2-S,S 4-electron donor has been previously evidenced for the cluster [Os6CO16(μ2-L1)], where L1 is bridging across an Os-Os edge via one of the sulfur atoms.

elements.content: In contrast to L1, its derivative 2-methyl-1,3-dithiane (L2) bearing a sterically more crowded substituent at the 2-position of the dithiane cycle, has been very scarcely probed as a ligand in coordination chemistry. The few representatives whose fluxional behavior has been investigated by NMR techniques in solution are [M­(CO)5(L2)] and [Fe­(CO)4(L2)]. According to a survey of the CSD database, there are no examples of crystallographically characterized coordination compounds ligated with alkyl- or aryl-substituted dithianes. Recently, we investigated in depth the reactivity of L2 toward CuI. When L2 and CuI were reacted in a 1:1 ratio, we evidenced the formation of two topological 1D (CP5) and 2D (CP4) isomers of formula [{Cu2I2}­(L2)2] n featuring dinuclear {Cu2(μ2-I)2} rhomboids. We also demonstrated that the network dimensionality can be controlled by the order of reactants addition. More interestingly, when 2 equiv of L2 was used, a strongly luminescent nonporous 3D coordination polymer [{Cu8(μ3-I)8}­(μ2-L2)4] n (CP6), incorporating unprecedented Cu8I8S8 clusters (built upon two side-fused open cubanes) was obtained (). We have furthermore shown that CP4 and CP5 can be converted in hot butyronitrile to strongly luminescent CP6. For comparison, we extended our study on the coordination chemistry of L2 toward CuBr and CuCl vs. CuI.
elements.clean_text:
Treatment of 2-Methyl-1,3-dithiane (L2) with CuX (X = I, Br, Cl) and CuCN

In contrast to L1, its derivative 2-methyl-1,3-dithiane (L2) bearing a sterically more crowded substituent at the 2-position of the dithiane cycle, has been very scarcely probed as a ligand in coordination chemistry. The few representatives whose fluxional behavior has been investigated by NMR techniques in solution are [M(CO)5(L2)] and [Fe(CO)4(L2)]. According to a survey of the CSD database, there are no examples of crystallographically characterized coordination compounds ligated with alkyl- or aryl-substituted dithianes. Recently, we investigated in depth the reactivity of L2 toward CuI. When L2 and CuI were reacted in a 1:1 ratio, we evidenced the formation of two topological 1D (CP5) and 2D (CP4) isomers of formula [{Cu2I2}(L2)2] n  featuring dinuclear {Cu2(μ2-I)2} rhomboids. We also demonstrated that the network dimensionality can be controlled by the order of reactants addition. More interestingly, when 2 equiv of L2 was used, a strongly luminescent nonporous 3D coordination polymer [{Cu8(μ3-I)8}(μ2-L2)4] n  (CP6), incorporating unprecedented Cu8I8S8 clusters (built upon two side-fused open cubanes) was obtained (). We have furthermore shown that CP4 and CP5 can be converted in hot butyronitrile to strongly luminescent CP6. For comparison, we extended our study on the coordination chemistry of L2 toward CuBr and CuCl vs. CuI.

elements.content: Addition of a slight excess of L2 to MeCN solutions of CuBr and CuCl resulted in fast deposition of large amounts of microcrystalline solids. X-ray suitable single crystals crystallizing in both cases in the monoclinic space group C2/m were obtained from dissolution of solid samples in hot EtCN or by slow partial evaporation of MeCN solutions. The crystal structures of the resulting 1D CPs [{Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n (CP7) and­[{Cu­(μ2-Cl)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n (CP8) shown in and (Figure S3 and S4) are isostructural with their iodo analogue [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n (CP5), constituting thus a unique case allowing a comparative description. The nonbonding Cu···Cu# contacts of the centrosymmetric [{Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu}]­rhomboids shorten systematically from 3.367 to 3.176 Å going from I to Br and reach 3.0517(8) Å for X = Cl. The Cu–X–Cu angles are not much affected by this shrinking of the Cu···Cu# contacts and evolve from 79.042(10)° (X = I) and 79.165(16)° (X = Br) to 79.851(16)° (X = Cl). Within this series, the Cu–S bond length falls with increasing electronegativity of the bridging halide from 2.3316(4) and 2.3097(6) to 2.3060(4) Å. We are not aware of other complete literature-known [{S2Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu}­S2] series. Note that an opposite evolution of the Cu···Cu separation is noticed in the case of the L1-ligated compound [{Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu}­(μ2-L1)2] n (CP1 and CP2) (X = I, Br; see above). The same tendency has been reported for the isomorphous molecular compounds [{Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu}­(μ-PhCH2SCH2CCCH2SCH2Ph)2], where in the case of X = I the Cu···Cu distance is shorter than for X = Br [2.9279(5) vs. 3.0075(5) Å]. The opposite trend has been noticed by Bowmaker et al. for 1:1:1 adducts of copper­(I) halides with phosphine and amine donor ligands, [{CuX­[PPh2(C6H4Me-o)]­(cpy)}2] (cpy = 4-cyanopyridine; X = Cl, Br or I). In this latter series, the Cu···Cu distances increase from 3.119(3) to 3.201(2) to 3.304(2) Å. Currently, we have no explanation to rationalize these findings.

elements.content: Although less common than CuX thioether adducts, the pseudohalide salt CuCN is also known to form both discrete molecular complexes and coordination polymers with varying dimensionalities upon treatment with thioether ligands. Examples are the dinuclear species [(9S3)­Cu­(μ2-CN)­(9S3)]­BF4(9S3 = 1,4,7-trithiacyclononane) or an 3D network of formula [(Cu­(μ2-CN)­(μ2-SMe2)] n . Another example of a 3D network assembled by tetrahydrothiophene ligands is [(Cu­(μ2-CN)­(μ2-THT)] n . When adding a slight excess of L2 to hot suspension of CuCN in MeCN, a greyish microcrystalline solid precipitated rapidly. We failed to obtain acceptable elemental analysis or PXRD data for this compound, which seems to lose progressively the somewhat volatile L2 ligand upon drying. The facile release of CuCN-bound ligands yielding CuCN has been evidenced by means of thermal analysis elsewhere.

Examples are the dinuclear species [(9S3)Cu(μ2-CN)(9S3)]BF4(9S3 = 1,4,7-trithiacyclononane) or an 3D network of formula [(Cu(μ2-CN)(μ2-SMe2)] n . Another example of a 3D network assembled by tetrahydrothiophene ligands is [(Cu(μ2-CN)(μ2-THT)] n . When adding a slight excess of L2 to hot suspension of CuCN in MeCN, a greyish microcrystalline solid precipitated rapidly. We failed to obtain acceptable elemental analysis or PXRD data for this compound, which seems to lose progressively the somewhat volatile L2 ligand upon drying. The facile release of CuCN-bound ligands yielding CuCN has been evidenced by means of thermal analysis elsewhere.

elements.content: Characteristic in the ATR-IR spectrum of CP9 () is the presence of an intense v(CN) vibration occurring at 2121 cm–1 indicative for a covalently bound cyanide ligand (Figure S33 ESI). As in other CuCN-based CPs ligated by donor ligands, the v(CN) stretch is markedly red-shifted compared to that of uncoordinated CuCN (2170 cm–1). Due to its poor solubility, a small amount of CP9 was redissolved in hot benzyl cyanide at 180 °C in the presence of L2 and then allowed to reach ambient temperature forming a product crystallizing in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21. A view of the corrugated 2D sheets of [(Cu­(μ2-CN)­(μ2-L2)] n (CP9) is shown in . The layers are constructed by two crystallographically different tetrahedral Cu1 and Cu2 centers, each one ligated by one C-bound cyanide, one N-bound cyanide from a neighbored Cu atom, and the S atoms of two L2 ligands. A view down the b axis on a 2D sheet of CP9 is given in Figure S5.

elements.content: View down the a axis of the 2D layer of [{Cu­(μ2-CN)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n (CP9). Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): Cu1–C5 1.935(3), Cu2–C6 1.920(3), Cu1–S1 2.3469(6), Cu2–S2 2.4032(6), Cu1–N2 2.006(6), Cu2–N1 2.015(3), C5–N1 1.142(4), C6–N2 1.153(4); S1–Cu1–S1 99.39(3), S2–Cu2–S2 95.64(3), S1–Cu1–S1 104.92(5), and N1–Cu2–S2 102.35(6).

Intrigued by the striking differences concerning the dimensionalities and nuclearities of the polymeric materials obtained from reaction of CuX with L1 and L2, we investigated also in detail the effect of the substitution at the 2-position by a bulkier isobutyl group. We therefore reacted first CuI with 2-isobutyl-1,3-dithiane (L3) in a 1:1 ratio (). A white precipitate immediately formed at room temperature. Dissolution of a small amount of this powder into hot acetonitrile led to the formation of the 2D CP10 of composition [{Cu3(μ3-I)­(μ2-I)2(μ2-L3)2}] n , which crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. Here again, addition of an excess of L3 (ratio 1:2) led to CP10 as proven by PXRD (Figure S21). The most salient feature in the crystal structure is the occurrence of triangular Cu3I3 SBUs, capped by a μ3-iodo ligand and two μ2-bond I atoms spanning two edges ( and S6). All Cu···Cu contacts are quite different ranging between weakly bonding (Cu2–Cu3 2.7625(3)), to clearly nonbonding (Cu1···Cu3 2.9554(3) and Cu1···Cu2 3.336 Å). The structure presents four nonequivalent sulfur atoms. The particularity is that the S3 atom acts as 4-electron donor while the others are only 2-electron donors. Thus, one isobutyl-1,3 dithiane ligand acts solely as a κ1S−κ1S ligand while the second one acts as a κ1S−μ2S ligand. The first dimension is maintained through the coordination of one ligand to two Cu3I3 SBUs, thus forming Cu1–S1–S2–Cu2 ribbons. The coordination of S3 to Cu1 and Cu2 and of S4 to Cu3 led to the second dimension, thus generating 19-membered macrocycles.
elements.clean_text:
Treatment of 2-Isobutyl-1,3-dithiane (L3) with CuX (X = I, Br, Cl)

Intrigued by the striking differences concerning the dimensionalities and nuclearities of the polymeric materials obtained from reaction of CuX with L1 and L2, we investigated also in detail the effect of the substitution at the 2-position by a bulkier isobutyl group. We therefore reacted first CuI with 2-isobutyl-1,3-dithiane (L3) in a 1:1 ratio (). A white precipitate immediately formed at room temperature. Dissolution of a small amount of this powder into hot acetonitrile led to the formation of the 2D CP10 of composition [{Cu3(μ3-I)(μ2-I)2(μ2-L3)2}] n , which crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. Here again, addition of an excess of L3 (ratio 1:2) led to CP10 as proven by PXRD (Figure S21). The most salient feature in the crystal structure is the occurrence of triangular Cu3I3 SBUs, capped by a μ3-iodo ligand and two μ2-bond I atoms spanning two edges ( and S6). All Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu contacts are quite different ranging between weakly bonding (Cu2-Cu3 2.7625(3)), to clearly nonbonding (Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu3 2.9554(3) and Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 3.336 Å). The structure presents four nonequivalent sulfur atoms. The particularity is that the S3 atom acts as 4-electron donor while the others are only 2-electron donors. Thus, one isobutyl-1,3 dithiane ligand acts solely as a κ1S-κ1S ligand while the second one acts as a κ1S-μ2S ligand. The first dimension is maintained through the coordination of one ligand to two Cu3I3 SBUs, thus forming Cu1-S1-S2-Cu2 ribbons. The coordination of S3 to Cu1 and Cu2 and of S4 to Cu3 led to the second dimension, thus generating 19-membered macrocycles.

Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): Cu1···Cu3 2.9554(3), Cu2–Cu3 2.7625(3), Cu1···Cu2 3.336 Cu1–I1 2.5910(2), Cu3–I1 2.6643(2), Cu1–I2 2.8034(2), Cu2–I2 2.8340(2), Cu3–I2 2.6486(2), Cu2–I3 2.5875(2), Cu3–I3 2.6481(2), Cu1–S1 2.3132(3), Cu1–S3 2.3179(3), Cu2–S3 2.2791(3), Cu2–S2 2.2976(3), Cu1–I1–Cu3 68.423(6), Cu1–I2–Cu2 72.560(6), Cu1–I2–Cu3 65.578(6), Cu2–I2–Cu3 60.400(6), Cu2–I3–Cu3 63.681(7), Cu1–S3–Cu2 93.047(12), S1–Cu1–S3 132.568(13), and S2–Cu2–S3 136.460 (13).

Several other examples of CPs incorporating trinuclear Cu3I x S3 (x = 3, 4) motifs such as catena-[tris­(μ3-I)-(μ2-I)-(ethyl-(N-ethyl-4-pyridinio)­sulfido)-tricopper­(I)] (EtS-4-C5H4NEt)­[Cu3I4], constructed of Cu3I4 – and EtS-C5H4N+Et components, are literature-known. The assembly of a 3D CP [(Cu3I3)­(thiacrown)·(MeCN)·(CH2Cl2)·(2H2O)] n by mixing calix[4]-bis­(thiacrown) with CuI in CH2Cl2 and MeCN has been reported by Lee et al. Upon removal of the coordinated solvent molecules by heating, the initial solvent-coordinated CP undergoes a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation to the desolvated polymer [(Cu3I3)­(thiacrown)·(0.5H2O)] n . For other Cu3I3-containing compounds, see also refs . There is also a report on the molecular compound [Cu3I4(dodecylMeS)3]­(dodecylMe2S) containing an anionic iodocuprate Cu3I4 – cluster with short Cu–Cu distances of 2.657 to 2.704 Å and a dodecyldimethylsulfonium cation as counterion. However, the structural features of CP10 differ considerably from those examples. Although the iodocuprates [Cu3I4(dodecylMeS)3]­[dodecylMe2S)] and (EtS-4-C5H4NEt)­[Cu3I4] incorporate like CP10 triangular Cu clusters, those triangles are far more symmetric with mean Cu–Cu distances below 2.8 Å. The SBUs of [(Cu3I3)­(thiacrown)·(MeCN)·(CH2Cl2)·(2H2O)] n do not form triangles, but are described as three-runged ladder type Cu3I3 units bearing exclusively μ2-bound iodo ligands. Although the two latter materials own also a Cu3I3S4 composition like CP10, there is one CuI unit without any Cu–S bond and two CuI units connected each to two S-donor sites.

There is also a report on the molecular compound [Cu3I4(dodecylMeS)3](dodecylMe2S) containing an anionic iodocuprate Cu3I4 - cluster with short Cu-Cu distances of 2.657 to 2.704 Å and a dodecyldimethylsulfonium cation as counterion. However, the structural features of CP10 differ considerably from those examples. Although the iodocuprates [Cu3I4(dodecylMeS)3][dodecylMe2S)] and (EtS-4-C5H4NEt)[Cu3I4] incorporate like CP10 triangular Cu clusters, those triangles are far more symmetric with mean Cu-Cu distances below 2.8 Å. The SBUs of [(Cu3I3)(thiacrown)⋅(MeCN)⋅(CH2Cl2)⋅(2H2O)] n  do not form triangles, but are described as three-runged ladder type Cu3I3 units bearing exclusively μ2-bound iodo ligands. Although the two latter materials own also a Cu3I3S4 composition like CP10, there is one CuI unit without any Cu-S bond and two CuI units connected each to two S-donor sites.

Unlike the Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu SBUs of CP2 and CP7, the two Cu atoms of CP11 are crystallographically different.

In order to evaluate the impact of a heteroelement at the 2-position of the dithiane cycle, we extended our systematic investigation on 2-trimethylsilyl-1,3-dithiane bearing a bulky SiMe3 group. A survey of the CSD database revealed that, apart from the dinuclear complex [Ag­(Me3Si-dithiane]2(CF3SO3)2 obtained by complexation of 2-trimethylsilyl-1,3-dithiane on silver triflate, no other examples of crystallographically characterized coordination compounds ligated with L4 have been reported so far.

In order to evaluate the impact of a heteroelement at the 2-position of the dithiane cycle, we extended our systematic investigation on 2-trimethylsilyl-1,3-dithiane bearing a bulky SiMe3 group. A survey of the CSD database revealed that, apart from the dinuclear complex [Ag(Me3Si-dithiane]2(CF3SO3)2 obtained by complexation of 2-trimethylsilyl-1,3-dithiane on silver triflate, no other examples of crystallographically characterized coordination compounds ligated with L4 have been reported so far.

elements.content: Addition of a stoichiometric amount of L4 to a MeCN solution of CuI caused fast precipitation of colorless solid, which, surprisingly had composition [(Cu2I2)­(L4)] indicating a 2:1 metal-to-ligand ratio (). Indeed, recrystallization of a sample of the collected material from hot MeCN afforded fine needle-shaped crystals whose crystallographic characterization confirmed this [(Cu2I2)­(L4)] composition. Note that this compound [{Cu2(μ4-I)­(μ2-I)}­(μ2-L4)] n (CP13) is markedly more soluble than CP1, CP4, and CP5, probably due the presence of the SiMe3 substituent.

elements.content: The crystal structure of the resulting 1D ribbon is shown in and S9 and diverges much from the Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu rhomboid containing 1D architectures of CP1 and CP5. The array of the crystallographically nonequivalent Cu1and Cu2 atoms may be considered as meander-shaped (when neglecting the long Cu2···Cu2 separation of 3.362 Å), with Cu1–Cu1 and Cu1–Cu2 distances of 2.8203(12) and 2.9838(9) Å, respectively. Each Cu1–Cu2 bond is quite symmetrically bridged by a μ2-type I2 atom with Cu1–I2 and Cu2–I2 distances of 2.6139(7) and 2.5930(7) Å, respectively. Particularly noteworthy is the capping of each Cu1–Cu1–Cu2–Cu2 segment by a μ4-type I1 ligand, with Cu–I distances ranging from 2.6139(7) to 2.7005(7) Å. The two sulfur atoms of L4 span additionally two remote Cu1 and Cu2 atoms with Cu1–S1 and Cu2–S2 bond lengths of 2.3053(11) and 2.3131(11) Å, respectively. shows also the alignment of the L4 ligands adopting a chair conformation with the SiMe3 groups pointing away from the inorganic [{Cu2(μ4-I)­(μ2-I)}] n ribbon.

With CuBr and L4, invariant of the metal-to-ligand ratio, formation of [{Cu2(μ4-Br)­(μ2-Br)}­μ2-L4)] n CP14 occurred, crystallizing like its CuI homologue CP13 as transparent needles in the monoclinic space group P21/n (). At first glance, the overall topology is very reminiscent to that of CP13 consisting of a 1D ribbon featuring both μ4-type and μ2-type halide ligands. However, a closer inspection of the structure shown in reveals that the symmetry is lowered since now four crystallographically different Cu atoms as well as four different S donor sites are present. The averaged Cu ···Cu distances are now somewhat longer than those of CP13 (3.063 vs. 3.055 Å), ranging from bonding (Cu2–Cu3 2.8159(3) Å) up to clearly nonbonding (Cu1···Cu4 3.409 Å). A perspective view of the packing down the c axis is presented in Figure S10.

elements.content: A structurally quite similar 1D ribbon [{Cu2(μ4-Cl)­(μ2-Cl)}­(μ2-L4)] n (CP15) crystallizing in the triclinic space group P1̅ was also isolated upon stoichiometric treatment of CuCl with L4 in MeCN solution. Whereas the Cu1–Cu1 distance of 2.883(3) Å is only slightly superior to that of CP12, both the Cu1···Cu2 and Cu2···Cu2 separations of 3.105 and 3.341 Å no longer allow describing the connectivity between the Cu atoms as meander-shaped. A description as discrete Cu1–Cu1 pairs, which are connected to isolated Cu2 atoms through μ2-bound Cl2 atoms and capping μ4-bound Cl2 atoms, appears to be more appropriate. The metric parameters are presented in the caption of , and a perspective view is shown in Figure S11.

elements.content: After the two reactants were mixed, the resulting colorless poorly soluble precipitate was heated shortly until complete dissolution by further addition of MeCN. Upon cooling, the onset of a crystal growth on the wall was noticed. Surprisingly, elemental analysis of the resulting needle-shaped material indicated a 2:1 CuI-to-L5 composition as well as the presence of MeCN molecules. Indeed, employing a 2:1 metal-to-ligand ratio allowed us to improve the yield up to 90%. An X-ray analysis of a single-crystal confirmed this composition, revealing also the existence of Cu-coordinated MeCN molecules. shows that an undulated 1D ribbon [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(MeCN)2(μ2-L5)] n (CP16) has been formed, consisting of rhomboid-shaped Cu2I2 SBUs linked by a L5 heterocycle via the S1 and S2 atoms. Noteworthy is the alternating occurrence of two different types of centrosymmetric rhomboids featuring slightly different metric parameters. In the Cu1–Cu1 SBU, the metal–metal bond 2.6555(10) Å is particularly short, whereas within the Cu2–Cu2 SBU, the bond distance reaches 2.7014(10) Å. Two μ2-spanning iodo ligands and a datively bound MeCN ligand with Cu–N distances of 1.967(4) and 1.982(4) Å complete the coordination of each copper center, respectively. A perspective view down the c axis is shown in Figure S12.

Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg) at 100 K: Cu1–Cu1# 2.6588(3), Cu2–Cu2# 2.7086(3), Cu1–I1 2.6339(2), Cu1#–I1 2.6764(2), Cu2–I2 2.6187(2), Cu2#–I2 2.6897(2), Cu1–S1 2.3193(3), Cu1–N1 1.9716(10), Cu2–S2 2.3324(3), Cu2–N2 1.9775(10); Cu1–I1–Cu1# 60.085(6), Cu2–I2–Cu2# 61.343(6), S1–Cu1–I1 98.984(11), and S2–Cu2–I2 102.224(10).

Examples of CPs incorporating two different types of Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu rhomboids within the same array are quite rare. We have encountered such a case in 1D CP­[{Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu}­(μ-p-MeC6H4SCH2CCCH2SC6H4Me-p)2] n, showing a regular alternation of Cu­(μ2-Br)2Cu SBUs (2.9662(14) Å) with a second type featuring somewhat shorter contacts (2.9306(14) Å). However, the difference in the Cu–Cu distance in CP16 is clearly more significant with Δ­(Cu–Cu 0.0489 Å). We therefore subjected a single-crystal stemming from another probe to a structural analysis at five different temperatures in a 100–300 K range. Whereas the metric parameters at 100 K are almost identical with those presented in the caption of , raising the temperature to 200 K causes a moderate lengthening of Cu1–Cu1 to 2.6731(7) Å and that of Cu2–Cu2 to 2.7114(7) Å. A phase transition (PT) occurs upon further heating to 250 K, resulting in a change of the space group from triclinic P1̅ to monoclinic P21/m. This change impacts the symmetry of the (MeCN)­SCu­(μ2-I)2CuS­(CNMe) units, which are now all crystallographically identical with a Cu–Cu distance of 2.6965(5) Å. Finally, an elongation of the latter bond distance to 2.7003(6) Å was observed when recording the structure at 300 K. The reversibility of this PT was evidence by a fast scan recording at 100 K, confirming reestablishment of the triclinic space group P1̅. Some relevant metric parameters are gathered in , and illustrations of the ribbons of CP16 at 100 and 300 K are shown in Figure S13. Although we have already observed a PT for the 1D CP [{Cu4(μ3-I)4}­{μ-PhSCH2SPh}2] n from C2/c to P21/c upon heating, the PT in the case of CP16 accompanied by an harmonization of the metric parameters is to the best of our knowledge unique. To confirm the occurrence of the PT, DSC analysis were performed from +20 to −80 °C (Figure S36). Upon cooling/heating, a pair of exothermic/endothermic peaks was observed at −52/–58 °C, indicating a reversible phase transition, in line with the PT observed by variable-temperature X-ray diffraction analysis in the 200–250 K range.

Intrigued by both the phase transition and the preference to ligate a labile MeCN donor in CP16 instead of coordination of a second L5 ligand, we repeated this reaction under more forcing conditions in hot EtCN employing a 2:1 stoichiometry. After reflux for 2 h, a homogeneous material crystallizing like CP16 in the triclinic space group P1̅ was isolated in over 90% yield. In contrast to CP16 exhibiting in the IR spectrum two weak peaks at 2309 and 2275 cm–1 due to the v(CN) vibration, the IR spectrum of this compound was silent in this region. In line with this finding the crystal structure of this air-stable polymeric material shown in revealed formation of 2D network of composition [{Cu3(μ3-I)­(μ2-I)2(μ2-L5)2}] (CP17), which is very reminiscent of CP10. Again, triangular Cu3I3 clusters capped by a μ3-iodo ligand and two μ2-bond I atom spanning two edges constitute the SBUs. But in contrast to CP10, all Cu···Cu distances are now above the sum of the van der Waals radii of two Cu atoms and range from weakly bonding (Cu1–Cu3 2.8302(4), Cu2–Cu3 2.8948(4) Å) to clearly nonbonding (Cu1···Cu2 3.297 Å). Thus, the mean Cu···Cu distance of the Cu3I3 triangle shortens from 3.0178 in CP10 to 3.007 Å in CP17. A view of the unit cell showing the stacking of the layers is presented in the Supporting Information as Figure S14.

An isomorphous 2D network with that of CP17 (triclinic, P1̅) results also from addition of L5 to a MeCN solution of CuBr ( and S15). Again, each trinuclear Cu cluster is linked to four adjacent Cu3Br3 SBUs through the S1 and S2 atoms of one L5 molecule acting as κ1S−κ1S ligand and the S3 and S4 atoms of a second L5 heterocycle linking in a κ1S−μ2S bonding mode, thus securing the 2-dimensional character of each layer featuring 20-membered macrocycles. Compared to CP17, the mean Cu···Cu distance of the Cu3X3 triangle shrinks only insignificantly (3.007 vs. 2.989 Å). A survey of the CSD database reveals another rare example of a Cu3Br3 cluster ligated by a thioether catena-(bis­(μ3-Br)­bis­(μ3-diallylsulfido)­tris­(μ2-Br)­pentacopper­(I), whose structure consists of infinite (Cu2Br2) n ribbons and Cu3Br3(diallysulfide)2 fragments that are linked to them through Cu–S and π-olefinic CC bonds.

When attempting to complete the series by complexation of L5 on CuCl at room temperature, elemental analysis on the crude precipitated compound indicates a 1:1 Cu: L5 ratio, different from the 3:2 Cu ratio expected for a compound related to CP17 and CP18. To grow a single crystal, the crude product was redissolved in hot EtCN. We failed to isolate a crystalline CuCl·L5 adduct but noticed the formation of a small amount of yellow crystals. An X-ray structure determination revealed formation of a 3D polymer containing −Cl–Cu-Cl–Cu–Cl– chains, assembled by five-membered 1,2-dithiolane ligands. Surprisingly, the same yellow material was formed using CuCl2 in MeCN solution. The PXRD of the crude product obtained by reaction of CuCl2 and L5 matches perfectly with the one calculated from the single crystals of the CP obtained from the reaction of CuCl with L5, confirming the formation of this compound as the main product (Figure S30). Mechanistic details rationalizing this unexpected extrusion of a Ph–CH unit (most probably in the form of benzaldehyde) and the structure of this 3D network will be reported elsewhere.

elements.content: The construction of polynuclear assemblies and coordination polymers featuring an organometallo-ligand, especially the electrochemically active and thermally robust ferrocenyl group in the main chain or as a pendant side-fragment, has stimulated much interest in material sciences. Coordination polymers based upon ferrocenyltelluroethers or ferrocenylselenoethers are precatalysts promoting Ullmann C–N cross-coupling reactions in solution. Reaction of metal ions with ferrocenes functionalized with bis­(thioether) substituents can give rise to the formation of discrete clusters. Introduction of an additional donor site as in the case of 1,1-(4-dipyridinethio)­ferrocene led to the formation of 1D CP when reacted with Cu­(I) salts. Recently, we reported on the complexation of the related five-membered ferrocenyl–dithiolane Fc-C­(H)­S2C2H4 on CuI and CuBr. A molecular heterometallic cluster [{Cu4(μ2-Br)2(μ3-Br)2}­(μ2-Fc-dithiolane)2(MeCN)2] was obtained with CuBr, while 1D polymeric [{Cu2(μ4-I)­(μ2-I)}­(μ2-Fc-dithiolane)] n has been assembled with CuI. We were now intrigued to combine a ferrocenyl fragment with the 1,3-dithiane cycle to assemble coordination networks based on CuX salt to investigate their architecture and to compare the findings with our recent investigations using ferrocenyl–dithiolane.
elements.clean_text:
Treatment of 2-Ferrocenyl-1,3-dithiane (L6) with CuI

The construction of polynuclear assemblies and coordination polymers featuring an organometallo-ligand, especially the electrochemically active and thermally robust ferrocenyl group in the main chain or as a pendant side-fragment, has stimulated much interest in material sciences. Coordination polymers based upon ferrocenyltelluroethers or ferrocenylselenoethers are precatalysts promoting Ullmann C-N cross-coupling reactions in solution. Reaction of metal ions with ferrocenes functionalized with bis(thioether) substituents can give rise to the formation of discrete clusters. Introduction of an additional donor site as in the case of 1,1-(4-dipyridinethio)ferrocene led to the formation of 1D CP when reacted with Cu(I) salts. Recently, we reported on the complexation of the related five-membered ferrocenyl-dithiolane Fc-C(H)S2C2H4 on CuI and CuBr. A molecular heterometallic cluster [{Cu4(μ2-Br)2(μ3-Br)2}(μ2-Fc-dithiolane)2(MeCN)2] was obtained with CuBr, while 1D polymeric [{Cu2(μ4-I)(μ2-I)}(μ2-Fc-dithiolane)] n  has been assembled with CuI. We were now intrigued to combine a ferrocenyl fragment with the 1,3-dithiane cycle to assemble coordination networks based on CuX salt to investigate their architecture and to compare the findings with our recent investigations using ferrocenyl-dithiolane.

elements.content: The synthesis of the heterocyclic dithioacetal Fc-C­(H)­S2C3H6 L6 has been first reported by treatment of ferrocenecarbaldehyde with 1,3-propanedithiol in the presence of HCl as catalyst. We have slightly modified the protocol using p-toluenesulfonic acid as catalyst. The crystal structure of this ferrocenyl–dithiane is shown in Figure S16, and the crystallographic refinement data are gathered in Table S7. The six-membered dithiane-heterocycle of L6 adopts the chair conformation as encountered in 2-phenyl-1,3-dithiane. Like the phenyl group in the latter thiaheterocycle, the ferrocenyl moiety occupies the equatorial position. The bond lengths and angles in L6 are normal for this kind of molecule and deserve no further comments.

The crystal structure of this ferrocenyl-dithiane is shown in Figure S16, and the crystallographic refinement data are gathered in Table S7. The six-membered dithiane-heterocycle of L6 adopts the chair conformation as encountered in 2-phenyl-1,3-dithiane. Like the phenyl group in the latter thiaheterocycle, the ferrocenyl moiety occupies the equatorial position. The bond lengths and angles in L6 are normal for this kind of molecule and deserve no further comments.

elements.content: As shown in , the outcome of the complexation of L6 on CuI in MeCN solution depends on the metal-to-ligand ratio and the order of reactant addition. A discrete molecular dinuclear species [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(κ1-L6)2(MeCN)2] D1 is formed, employing a 1:1 ratio. The crystal structure of this dimer depicted in shows a centrosymmetric Cu2I2 rhomboid in which the two Cu atoms are connected through a quite short Cu–Cu bond of only 2.6897(4) Å. The coordination sphere around each Cu center is completed by a datively bound MeCN ligand and one S atom of L6. Surprisingly, the bonding mode of L6 is monohapto, with the second S atom prone for coordination of a second metal center. A bridging μ2-bonding of L6 can be achieved by performing the reaction in a 2:1 CuI-to-ligand ratio. Indeed, when L6 was added to 2 equiv of CuI, PXRD analysis confirmed the formation of D1, while when adding 2 equiv of CuI to L6, an orange-colored crystalline solid [{Cu­(μ3-I)2Cu}­(μ-L6)] n (CP19) was isolated. The unusual 1D-polymeric architecture of CP19 is illustrated in . The inorganic CuI ribbon of this material contains tetranuclear open Cu4I4 clusters as SBUs with a mean Cu–Cu distance of 2.7384 Å, below the sum of the van der Waals radii of two Cu atoms. These tetranuclear units, capped by two μ3-type I2 atoms, are interconnected to adjacent ones through much looser Cu2···Cu2# contacts of 3.224(8) Å and two μ3-bridging I1atoms with Cu–I1 bond distances ranging from 2.6555(8) to 2.6844(8) Å. D1 exhibits in the IR spectrum two weak peaks at 2305 and 2275 cm–1 due to the v(CN) vibration (Figure S35). The structure of CP19 differs from that encountered in the CP obtained by reaction of 2 equiv of CuI with the less flexible 2-ferrocenyl-1,3-dithiolane ligand. In this latter case, the infinite ribbon was described as a meander-shaped array containing both μ4 and μ2-I ligands.

All compounds were found to be stable for several months under ambient atmosphere. The thermal properties of some selected CPs containing L2 (CP5, CP7, and CP8), L3 (CP10, CP11, and CP12) and ferrocenyl L6 ligands (CP19) were studied by TGA under air up to 850 °C. The first derivative plots of the TGA traces are given in the Supporting Information (Figures S37–S44) Temperatures of decomposition corresponding to a 5% loss of the total mass are given in . The thermogravimetric traces depicted in show that CPs containing L2 and L3 ligands present relatively identical thermal behavior. As already encountered for other thioether-based CPs, all thermal profiles of CPs containing bromide (CP7 and CP11) or chlorine (CP8) atoms present three main losses while the thermal decomposition of CP5 and CP10 containing iodide presents only two good decomposition steps. The first major weight loss can be attributed to the loss of ligands based on the comparison between the theoretical and experimental values (see ). The final residual contents values are also close to those calculated based on the formation of CuO. Comparison of the traces between CP7 and CP8 within the L2 series and between CP11 and CP12 within the L3 series indicates that, independent of the dimensionality (1D or 2D), a higher stability is always obtained for CP containing Cu2Br2 SBUs than those containing Cu2Cl2 rhomboids. This observation is consistent with our previous studies. It was however more difficult to obtain a tendency for CPs containing iodide. Compared to CP7 and CP8, the 1D CP5 that contains Cu2I2 rhomboids presents a lower thermal stability. Opposite to this, in the L3 series, the thermal stability of CP10 is higher than those of CP11 and CP12. In this case, the highest stability might be due to the presence of a Cu3I3 core. Comparison of thermal degradation temperatures between CP7 and CP11 containing Cu2Br2 rhomboids and between CP8 and CP12 containing Cu2Cl2 rhomboids indicates that L2 containing CPs (CP7 and CP8) are more stable than L3 containing materials (CP11 and CP12). One explanation that has already been suggested for this behavior is the difference in the boiling point value of the ligand. However, in our case, the boiling point of L3 (250 °C) is higher than that of L2 (224 °C). The dimer compound D1 presents the lowest stability with a first degradation step from 60 to 130 °C attributed to the loss of coordinated acetonitrile (). After that initial decomposition step, the thermal degradation profiles of D1 and CP19 look alike. The final residues might include both FeO and CuO as evidenced by a comparison between theoretical and experimental values.

Thermal Properties

Opposite to this, in the L3 series, the thermal stability of CP10 is higher than those of CP11 and CP12. In this case, the highest stability might be due to the presence of a Cu3I3 core. One explanation that has already been suggested for this behavior is the difference in the boiling point value of the ligand. However, in our case, the boiling point of L3 (250 °C) is higher than that of L2 (224 °C). The dimer compound D1 presents the lowest stability with a first degradation step from 60 to 130 °C attributed to the loss of coordinated acetonitrile (). After that initial decomposition step, the thermal degradation profiles of D1 and CP19 look alike. The final residues might include both FeO and CuO as evidenced by a comparison between theoretical and experimental values.

(CuI) n -containing coordination polymers are known for their interesting luminescence properties. Here, CP1, CP10, CP13, and CP17 composed of different SBUs and networks were found to be only weakly emissive under a UV lamp at 366 nm. In these cases, the mean Cu···Cu separation lies above the sum of the van der Waals radii of two copper atoms. However, taking into account that both CP16 and CP19 present relatively short Cu–Cu distances (2.6555 and 2.7215 Å, respectively), we were intrigued to measure their luminescence spectra. CP16 was found to be highly luminescent under UV irradiation (Figure S47). The luminescence spectrum of CP16 recorded at 298 K presents two emission bands at high energy (HE) and low energy (LE) with maxima at 435 and 554 nm ( and ). Other examples of CPs containing Cu2I2 rhomboids with luminescence spectra exhibiting a band at high energy around 430 nm with a long tail spreading over 550 nm have been reported before. This includes rhomboids obtained by reaction of CuI with (i) 1,4-bis­(cyclohexylthio)­butane, (ii) 1,5-bis­(p-tolylthio)­pentane or 1,5-bis­(p-phenylthio)­pentane, and (iii) trans-1,4-bis­(p-phenylthio)-2-butene. Our luminescence spectra, with two well-separated emission bands, looks much like the one reported for a CP obtained by coordination of CuI with the 1,2-dithiane ligand. At 77 K, only one emission band with maxima at 435 nm is observed and the intensity of this band is much higher than at room temperature (see Figure S45). The presence of a second band at low energy and the associated luminescence thermochromism phenomenon was also described for cubane-type species such as Cu4I4(pyridine)4 or other copper iodide clusters containing phosphine ligands. Interestingly, we also found out that, as in the case of [Cu4I4(pyridine)4], the LE and HE bands display different excitation spectra with reverse order: HE and LE missions correspond to the LE and HE excitation. We are not aware of any cubane-type CPs composed of thioether ligands showing disappearance of the low-energy band upon cooling. A plausible explanation that may come to mind is the contamination by another cubane species as reported in the literature. However, as stipulated before, CP16 is highly luminescent under a UV lamp, and the crude powder can be considered as pure (based on the comparison of experimental and simulated PXRD patterns (Figure S26) and elemental analysis results). We have shown above that CP16 undergoes a phase transition at around −50 °C leading to a shortening of the Cu–Cu distance upon cooling. Currently, we are unable to conclude if this PT is responsible for the observed different luminescent properties at 298 and 77 K. Further computational studies and solid-state emission lifetimes are necessary to address this question to attribute the nature of the involved transitions.

In these cases, the mean Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation lies above the sum of the van der Waals radii of two copper atoms. elements.content: The luminescence of CP19 presenting an unprecedented SBU is somehow different. The spectrum presents an intense band at HE, centered at 436 nm, and a second broad band of lower intensity located at 536 nm. These two bands exhibit same excitation spectra. At 77 K, the luminescence profile remains the same even though the intensities of the two emission bands are stronger (Figure S46). These spectra are thus more reminiscent to those reported for thioether-based CPs containing Cu2I2 rhomboids.

elements.content: In this project, we described a complete series of CPs obtained by reacting 2-substituted-1,3-dithiane with CuX salts, where X = I, Br, and Cl. First, we have extended the work of Keller and Knaust on the coordination of 1,3-dithiane (L1) on [Cu­(MeCN)4]­BF4 covering the complete Cu­(I) halide series and shown that, in this latter case, the resulting CPs contain invariable Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu rhomboids as SBUs instead of a single Cu­(I) center as in the former case. Another novel finding is the aptitude of L1 to coordinate as a μ2-S,S 4-electron donor using the two nonbonding doublets of each S atom. The structural diversity of the architectures is further enriched when using dithiane derivatives that are monosubstituted at the 2-position of the thiaheterocycle. Even the “innocent” replacement of an H atom by a methyl group in L2 allows us, in the case of CuI, to modulate the dimensionality of the network from 1D to 3D and the nuclearity of the (CuI) n SBUs as a function of the reaction conditions and of CuI-to-L2 ratio. The crystallographic characterization of the isostructural series [{Cu­(μ2-X)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n CP4, CP7 and CP8 allowed also for the first time to correlate the Cu···Cu distances with the nature of the bridging halide. Although cyano groups in CuCN compounds may adopt a bridging μ2-bonding mode via the C atom, no such CN bonding occurs in [{Cu­(μ2-CN)2Cu}­(μ2-L2)2] n (CP9) but instead a linear Cu–CN–Cu linking is preferred. The use of the bulkier L3 ligand bearing an isobutyl group gives rise to a 2D material CP10 featuring a hitherto unknown [{Cu3(μ3-I)­(μ2-I)2}­S4] cluster architecture. Similarly, the use of L5 bearing a phenyl group at the 2-position allows us to generate 2D networks featuring similar unprecedented [{Cu3(μ3-I)­(μ2-I)2}­S4] and [{Cu3(μ3-Br)­(μ2-Br)2}­S4] cluster cores encountered in CP17 and CP18. In the case of L4 bearing a SiMe3 function at the 2-position, independent of the halide nature, 1D ribbons featuring both μ4-type and μ2-type halide ligands were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this project, we described a complete series of CPs obtained by reacting 2-substituted-1,3-dithiane with CuX salts, where X = I, Br, and Cl. First, we have extended the work of Keller and Knaust on the coordination of 1,3-dithiane (L1) on [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 covering the complete Cu(I) halide series and shown that, in this latter case, the resulting CPs contain invariable Cu(μ2-X)2Cu rhomboids as SBUs instead of a single Cu(I) center as in the former case. Another novel finding is the aptitude of L1 to coordinate as a μ2-S,S 4-electron donor using the two nonbonding doublets of each S atom. The structural diversity of the architectures is further enriched when using dithiane derivatives that are monosubstituted at the 2-position of the thiaheterocycle. Even the "innocent" replacement of an H atom by a methyl group in L2 allows us, in the case of CuI, to modulate the dimensionality of the network from 1D to 3D and the nuclearity of the (CuI) n  SBUs as a function of the reaction conditions and of CuI-to-L2 ratio. The crystallographic characterization of the isostructural series [{Cu(μ2-X)2Cu}(μ2-L2)2] n  CP4, CP7 and CP8 allowed also for the first time to correlate the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances with the nature of the bridging halide. Although cyano groups in CuCN compounds may adopt a bridging μ2-bonding mode via the C atom, no such CN bonding occurs in [{Cu(μ2-CN)2Cu}(μ2-L2)2] n  (CP9) but instead a linear Cu-CN-Cu linking is preferred. The use of the bulkier L3 ligand bearing an isobutyl group gives rise to a 2D material CP10 featuring a hitherto unknown [{Cu3(μ3-I)(μ2-I)2}S4] cluster architecture. Similarly, the use of L5 bearing a phenyl group at the 2-position allows us to generate 2D networks featuring similar unprecedented [{Cu3(μ3-I)(μ2-I)2}S4] and [{Cu3(μ3-Br)(μ2-Br)2}S4] cluster cores encountered in CP17 and CP18. In the case of L4 bearing a SiMe3 function at the 2-position, independent of the halide nature, 1D ribbons featuring both μ4-type and μ2-type halide ligands were obtained.

elements.content: The observation that in several examples the S atoms of L1, L3, and L5 may act as both 2-electron and 4-electron donors also contributes certainly to the structural richness of the numerous architectures presented in this exhaustive study. Although the luminescent closed-cubane cluster of type [Cu4(μ3-I)4L4] is a widespread motif often obtained by treatment of CuI with N-, P-, As-, and Sb-donor ligands that also results by coordination of simple sulfides such as Pr–S–Pr, cyclic thioethers such as tetrahydrothiophene and tetrahydrothiopyran, as well as numerous dithioethers RS∩SR, it is surprising that this cubane motif is not encountered using 1,3-dithianes. However, the formation of the octanuclear cluster SBU in [{Cu8(μ3-I)8}­(μ2-L2)4] n (CP6) demonstrates that also in the case of dithianes, aggregation of CuX to clusters with a nuclearity >3 can occur.
elements.clean_text: The observation that in several examples the S atoms of L1, L3, and L5 may act as both 2-electron and 4-electron donors also contributes certainly to the structural richness of the numerous architectures presented in this exhaustive study. Although the luminescent closed-cubane cluster of type [Cu4(μ3-I)4L4] is a widespread motif often obtained by treatment of CuI with N-, P-, As-, and Sb-donor ligands that also results by coordination of simple sulfides such as Pr-S-Pr, cyclic thioethers such as tetrahydrothiophene and tetrahydrothiopyran, as well as numerous dithioethers RS∩SR, it is surprising that this cubane motif is not encountered using 1,3-dithianes. However, the formation of the octanuclear cluster SBU in [{Cu8(μ3-I)8}(μ2-L2)4] n  (CP6) demonstrates that also in the case of dithianes, aggregation of CuX to clusters with a nuclearity >3 can occur.

elements.content: To conclude, despite the difficulty to anticipate the architecture generated by the self-assembly process between copper salts and dithianes, we have shown at least that (i) using CuBr and CuCl, the resulting CPs show the same dimensionalities and SBUs (except in one case with L1); (ii) using CuI, functionalization of the dithiane ligand at the 2-position with a bulky group (phenyl, isobutyl) affords 2D CPs incorporating Cu3I3 SBUs. The bulkier ferrocenyl-derivative L6 also leads to the formation of a 1D CP with μ3-I capped Cu centers. Independent of the nature of the halide, the −SiMe3 bearing ligand L4 led to the crystallogenesis of 1D CPs containing a [Cu2(μ4-X)­(μ2-X)] SBU. We have also shown that the dimensionality of all compounds is quite variable ranging from 0D in the molecular ferrocenyl compound [{Cu­(μ2-I)2Cu}­(κ1-L6)2(MeCN)2 (D1) to 3D in [{Cu8(μ3-I)8}­(μ2-L2)4] n (CP6). We are convinced that further variation of the reaction conditions or substituent-pattern around the dithiane framework may also permit us to generate networks incorporating luminescent closed-cubane type [Cu4(μ3-I)4 dithiane4] SBUs. We are currently extending these investigations to other functionalized dithianes bearing chromophores such as anthracenyl groups for photophysical studies and intend to investigate more in depth the electrochemical properties of our ferrocenyl-dithiane based materials.

The bulkier ferrocenyl-derivative L6 also leads to the formation of a 1D CP with μ3-I capped Cu centers. elements.content: The CuX salts L1–L5, 1,2-ethanedithiol, and ferrocenecarbaldehyde were commercially obtained from Acros, Alfa Aesar, and Aldrich. The preparation of CP4, CP5, and CP6 has been recently described. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker AVANCE 400 HD instrument. 1H chemical shifts were referenced to the proton impurity of the NMR solvent and 13C chemical shifts to the NMR solvent. The solid-state emission and excitation spectra were recorded at room temperature or 77 K with a Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrometer using a cylindrical 5 mm diameter quartz capillary with a scan speed of 1 nm/s. Infrared spectra were recorded with a 2 cm–1 resolution on a Bruker vertex70 FTIR spectrometer using a Platinum ATR accessory equipped with a diamond crystal. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a TA Instruments Q600 in an alumina crucible under an air flow with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 up to 850 °C. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements of phase-transition temperatures were performed with a TA Instruments Q100. Samples of 5–10 mg were placed in a hermetically sealed aluminum pan; an empty pan was used as the reference. Pans were exposed to a N2 flow atmosphere. The following measurement conditions were applied: (i) cooling from room temperature to −80 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1; (ii) heating to 25 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The CuX salts L1-L5, 1,2-ethanedithiol, and ferrocenecarbaldehyde were commercially obtained from Acros, Alfa Aesar, and Aldrich. The preparation of CP4, CP5, and CP6 has been recently described. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker AVANCE 400 HD instrument. 1H chemical shifts were referenced to the proton impurity of the NMR solvent and 13C chemical shifts to the NMR solvent. The solid-state emission and excitation spectra were recorded at room temperature or 77 K with a Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrometer using a cylindrical 5 mm diameter quartz capillary with a scan speed of 1 nm/s. Infrared spectra were recorded with a 2 cm-1 resolution on a Bruker vertex70 FTIR spectrometer using a Platinum ATR accessory equipped with a diamond crystal. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a TA Instruments Q600 in an alumina crucible under an air flow with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 up to 850 °C. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements of phase-transition temperatures were performed with a TA Instruments Q100. Samples of 5-10 mg were placed in a hermetically sealed aluminum pan; an empty pan was used as the reference. Pans were exposed to a N2 flow atmosphere. The following measurement conditions were applied: (i) cooling from room temperature to -80 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1; (ii) heating to 25 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1.

elements.content: X-ray powder patterns were obtained at 295 K on a D8 Advance Bruker diffractometer using Ni-filtered Kα radiation. Single crystals of CP1–CP19 and D1 were mounted on a Bruker D8 Venture four-circle diffractometer equipped with a nitrogen jet stream low-temperature system (Oxford Cryosystems). The X-ray source was graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) from a microfocus sealed tube IμS by Incoatec. In the case of CP12, the X-ray source was a microfocus sealed tube IμS 3.0 by Incoatec. For CP1, CP2, CP3, CP7, CP8, CP13, CP19, and D1, a Photon 100 CMOS detector by Bruker was used. Data collection for CP9–CP12 and CP14–CP18 was conducted with a Bruker Photon II CPAD detector. All data collections have been carried out at 100 K; in the case of CP16, data were collected at five different temperatures: 100, 150, 200, 250, and 300 K, using the same crystal. The lattice parameters were obtained by least-squares fit to the optimized setting angles of the entire set of collected reflections. Intensity data were recorded as φ and ω scans with κ offsets. No significant intensity decay or temperature drift was observed during data collections. Data were reduced by using SAINT v8.37A (Bruker, 2015) software, and absorption correction was carried out by SADABS-2016/2 (Bruker, 2016). The structure was solved using SHELXT (Sheldrick, 2015) with intrinsic phasing. Refinements were carried out by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL program (Sheldrick, 2015) on the complete set of reflections. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, whereas the H atoms were treated in a riding mode. The crystal structure determination of L6 was accomplished on an Oxford Xcalibur Sapphire3 diffractometer: data collection, CrysAlis CCD (Oxford Diffraction, 2006); cell refinement, CrysAlis RED (Oxford Diffraction, 2006); data reduction, CrysAlis RED; absorption correction, multiscan (CrysAlis RED; Oxford Diffraction, 2006).

X-ray powder patterns were obtained at 295 K on a D8 Advance Bruker diffractometer using Ni-filtered Kα radiation. Single crystals of CP1-CP19 and D1 were mounted on a Bruker D8 Venture four-circle diffractometer equipped with a nitrogen jet stream low-temperature system (Oxford Cryosystems). The X-ray source was graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) from a microfocus sealed tube IμS by Incoatec. In the case of CP12, the X-ray source was a microfocus sealed tube IμS 3.0 by Incoatec. For CP1, CP2, CP3, CP7, CP8, CP13, CP19, and D1, a Photon 100 CMOS detector by Bruker was used. Data collection for CP9-CP12 and CP14-CP18 was conducted with a Bruker Photon II CPAD detector. All data collections have been carried out at 100 K; in the case of CP16, data were collected at five different temperatures: 100, 150, 200, 250, and 300 K, using the same crystal. The lattice parameters were obtained by least-squares fit to the optimized setting angles of the entire set of collected reflections. Intensity data were recorded as φ and ω scans with κ offsets. No significant intensity decay or temperature drift was observed during data collections. Data were reduced by using SAINT v8.37A (Bruker, 2015) software, and absorption correction was carried out by SADABS-2016/2 (Bruker, 2016). The structure was solved using SHELXT (Sheldrick, 2015) with intrinsic phasing. Refinements were carried out by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL program (Sheldrick, 2015) on the complete set of reflections. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, whereas the H atoms were treated in a riding mode. The crystal structure determination of L6 was accomplished on an Oxford Xcalibur Sapphire3 diffractometer: data collection, CrysAlis CCD (Oxford Diffraction, 2006); cell refinement, CrysAlis RED (Oxford Diffraction, 2006); data reduction, CrysAlis RED; absorption correction, multiscan (CrysAlis RED; Oxford Diffraction, 2006).

Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. The CIF files for the X-ray structures presented in this publication have the following CCDC numbers: 1888353 for CP1, 1888455 for CP2, 1888456 for CP3, 1888460 for CP7, 1888477 for CP8, 1888478 for CP9, 1888479 for CP10, 1888480 for CP11, 1888481 for CP12, 1888483 for CP13, 1888487 for CP14, 1888489 for CP15, 1886853–1886857 for CP16 at 100, 150, 200, 250, and 300 K, 1888490 for CP17, 1888497 for CP18, 1888515 for CP19,1888524 for D1, and 1888541 for L6. These data may be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center through www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: A toluene solution of ferrocenecarbaldehyde (428 mg, 2 mmol) and 1,3-propanedithiol (260 mg, 2.4 mmol) was stirred at 60 °C with p-toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (38 mg, 0.2 mmol) as a catalyst. elements.content: To an EtCN solution of CuI (382 mg, 2.0 mmol) (40 mL) was added neat 1,3-dithiane (252 mg, 2.1 mmol). A white precipitate appeared within 2 min. The mixture was stirred for 3 h to complete the reaction and then heated to reflux for 5 min. After the reaction was allowed to reach ambient temperature, the precipitate was filtered off, washed with 5 mL of propionitrile, and dried to give CP1 as a white microcystalline solid (566 mg, 91%). Conducting the reaction in MeCN using a 2:1 CuI-to-L1 ratio afforded the same product. X-ray suitable crystals were grown by dissolution of a small amount of CP1 in refluxing EtCN and subsequent slow cooling in an oil bath. Mp: 241 °C. IR (ATR): 2985 (w), 2952 (w), 2913 (w), 2902 (w), 1428 (m), 1417 (s), 1405 (m), 1389­(w), 1366 (m), 1283 (w), 1242 (w), 1164 (m), 1082 (m), 1012 (m), 923 (s), 914 (s), 891 (m), 889 (w), 817 (m), 746 (s), 738 (s), 664 (s), 637 (m), 476 (m) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C4H8CuIS2 (310.66): C, 15.46; H, 2.60; S, 20.64. Found: C, 15.05; H, 2.24; S, 20.35.

elements.content: To a solution of 1,3-dithiane (252 mg, 2.1 mmol) in 20 mL of acetonitrile was added CuBr (286 mg, 2.0 mmol) in several portions. A white precipitate appeared within 5 min. The mixture was stirred for 3 h to complete the reaction and then heated to reflux for 3 min until almost entire dissolution of the solid. Upon cooling, the onset of progressive growth of colorless crystals occurred on the wall of the Schlenk tube. A further crop of crystals of CP2 could be isolated after decanting the slight greenish mother liquor and storage at 5 °C overnight in a refrigerator. Overall yield: 406 mg, 69%. Mp: 238 °C; IR (ATR): 2960 (m), 2934 (w), 2910 (w), 2896 (m), 1416 (m), 1365 (w), 1276 (w), 1234 (m), 1163 (m), 1090 (w), 1018 (m), 921 (s), 888 (m), 819 (m), 747 (m), 725 (m), 666 (m), 659 (m), 648 (m), 630 (m), 488 (m), 477 (m) cm–1. A white precipitate was observed within 5 min. The mixture was then stirred for 3 h to complete the reaction. The precipitate was filtered, washed with 2 × 10 mL of acetonitrile, and dried. CP10 was isolated as a white solid (173 mg, 46%). A small amount of this CP (20 mg) was dissolved in hot MeCN (10 mL). Overnight standing of the solution at 5 °C provided single-crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography. IR (ATR): 3057 (w), 3031 (w), 2988 (w), 2949 (w), 2904 (w), 2818 (w), 1584 (w), 1494 (w), 1452 (w), 1418 (m), 1273 (w), 1221 (w), 1158 (w), 1072 (w), 1032 (w), 1009 (w), 905 (w), 877 (w), 837 (w), 780 (w), 727 (m), 690 (s), 667 (w), 645 (w), 490 (w) cm-1. elements.content: To a solution of L6 (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added a MeCN solution of CuI (38 mg, 0.2 mmol). After 2 h of stirring, a yellow precipitate was obtained, which was dissolved by heating. The solution was cooled to room temperature and then kept at 5 °C. Overnight standing gave orange crystals, which were filtered off and air-dried to give CP19 (45 mg, 66% yield). Mp: 197 °C. IR (ATR): 2955 (w), 2922 (w), 2900 (w), 2858 (w), 1468 (w), 1414 (m), 1270 (w), 1253 (m), 1167 (m), 1083 (w), 1042 (w), 999, 905 (m), 881 (m), 840 (s), 758 (m), 731 (w), 701 (w), 639 (w), 483 (w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C14H16FeCu2I2S2 (685.16): C, 24.54; H, 2.35; S, 9.36. Found: C, 24.97; H, 2.50; S, 9.79.
