cln_elements.content:
A toluene solution of ferrocenecarbaldehyde (428 mg, 2 mmol) and 1,3-propanedithiol (260 mg, 2.4 mmol) was stirred at 60 °C with p-toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (38 mg, 0.2 mmol) as a catalyst. After 24 h, the solvent was evaporated and the residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel eluting with a gradient of hexane/dichloromethane (100:0 to 80:20) to give L6 as an orange solid (465 mg, 76%), mp 115–116 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3), δ (ppm): 1.79–1.86 (m, 1H), 2.05–2.09 (m, 1H), 2.75–5.80 (m, 2H), 2.91–2.98 (m, 2H), 4.08 (t, 3 J = 2.0 Hz, 2H), 4.18 (s, 5H), 4.26 (t, 3 J = 2.0 Hz, 2H), 4.90 (s, 1H). 13C­{1H} NMR (CDCl3), δ (ppm): 25.7, 31.9, 47.3, 67.4, 68.0, 69.5, 86.9. IR (ATR): 3111 (w), 3092­(w), 2931 (w), 2891 (w), 1410 (w), 1274 (w), 1238 (w), 1178 (w), 1106 (m), 1038 (w), 1021 (w), 1001 (m), 929 (w), 904 (w), 874 (w), 815 (m), 775 (m), 725 (w), 679 (w), 654 (w), 620 (w), 493 (s), 483 (s), 418 (w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C14H16FeS2 (304.25): C, 55.27; H, 5.30; S, 21.08. Found: C, 55.63; H, 5.36; S, 21.12.

Synthesis of <bold>CP1</bold>

To an EtCN solution of CuI (382 mg, 2.0 mmol) (40 mL) was added neat 1,3-dithiane (252 mg, 2.1 mmol). A white precipitate appeared within 2 min. The mixture was stirred for 3 h to complete the reaction and then heated to reflux for 5 min. After the reaction was allowed to reach ambient temperature, the precipitate was filtered off, washed with 5 mL of propionitrile, and dried to give CP1 as a white microcystalline solid (566 mg, 91%). Conducting the reaction in MeCN using a 2:1 CuI-to-L1 ratio afforded the same product. X-ray suitable crystals were grown by dissolution of a small amount of CP1 in refluxing EtCN and subsequent slow cooling in an oil bath. Mp: 241 °C. IR (ATR): 2985 (w), 2952 (w), 2913 (w), 2902 (w), 1428 (m), 1417 (s), 1405 (m), 1389­(w), 1366 (m), 1283 (w), 1242 (w), 1164 (m), 1082 (m), 1012 (m), 923 (s), 914 (s), 891 (m), 889 (w), 817 (m), 746 (s), 738 (s), 664 (s), 637 (m), 476 (m) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C4H8CuIS2 (310.66): C, 15.46; H, 2.60; S, 20.64. Found: C, 15.05; H, 2.24; S, 20.35.

Synthesis of <bold>CP2</bold>

To a solution of 1,3-dithiane (252 mg, 2.1 mmol) in 20 mL of acetonitrile was added CuBr (286 mg, 2.0 mmol) in several portions. A white precipitate appeared within 5 min. The mixture was stirred for 3 h to complete the reaction and then heated to reflux for 3 min until almost entire dissolution of the solid. Upon cooling, the onset of progressive growth of colorless crystals occurred on the wall of the Schlenk tube. A further crop of crystals of CP2 could be isolated after decanting the slight greenish mother liquor and storage at 5 °C overnight in a refrigerator. Overall yield: 406 mg, 69%. Mp: 238 °C; IR (ATR): 2960 (m), 2934 (w), 2910 (w), 2896 (m), 1416 (m), 1365 (w), 1276 (w), 1234 (m), 1163 (m), 1090 (w), 1018 (m), 921 (s), 888 (m), 819 (m), 747 (m), 725 (m), 666 (m), 659 (m), 648 (m), 630 (m), 488 (m), 477 (m) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C4H8BrCuS2 (263.69): C, 18.22; H, 3.06; S, 24.32. Found: C, 17.91; H, 2.84; S, 24.05.

Synthesis of <bold>CP3</bold>

To a solution of 1,3-dithiane (252 mg, 2.1 mmol) in 25 mL of acetonitrile containing 1 mL of MeOH was added CuCl (404 mg, 4.0 mmol) in several portions. A yellowish precipitate formed rapidly. The mixture was stirred for 3 h to complete the reaction and then heated to reflux for 3 min until almost entire dissolution of the solid. Upon cooling, the onset of progressive growth of yellowish crystals occurred on the wall of the Schlenk tube. A further crop of crystals of CP3 could be isolated by decanting the greenish mother liquor and storage at 5 °C overnight in a refrigerator. Overall yield: 540 mg, 85%. Mp: 241 °C. IR (ATR): 2961 (m), 2897 (m), 1424 (m), 1275 (w), 1234 (m), 1164 (m), 1148 (m), 1103­(m), 1020 (m), 1001 (m), 920 (s), 889 (m), 821 (m), 775 (w), 729 (m), 652 (m), 634 (m), 490 (s), 419 (m) cm–1 Anal. Calcd for C4H8Cl2Cu2S2 (318.24): C, 15.91; H, 2.53; S, 20.15. Found: C, 16.21; H, 2.84; S, 20.55.

Synthesis of <bold>CP7</bold>

This compound was prepared in a manner similar to that detailed for CP2. Overall yield: 487 mg, 88%. Mp: 225 °C. IR (ATR): 2956 (w), 2940 (w), 2912 (w), 28962 (w), 1453 (w), 1425 (s), 1408 (m), 1376 (m), 1231 (m), 1181 (m), 1164 (m), 1126 (m), 1078 (w), 1064 (m), 966 (s), 902 (m), 872 (m), 8112 (m), 710 (m), 664 (s) cm–1 Anal. Calcd for C5H10BrCuS2 (277.72): C, 28.77; H, 3.63; S, 23.09. Found: C, 28.31; H, 3.34; S, 22.75.

Synthesis of <bold>CP8</bold>

This compound was prepared in a manner similar to that detailed for CP3 . Overall yield: 373 mg, 79%. Mp: 198 °C. IR (ATR): 2959 (m), 2918 (w), 2863 (w), 2829 (w), 1456 (w), 1427 (s), 1410 (m), 1376 (m), 1233 (m), 1183 (w), 1165 (s), 1128 (m), 1080 (m), 902 (s), 872 (m), 810 (m), 712 (m), 665 (s), 444 (w) cm–1 Anal. Calcd for C5H10ClCuS2 (233.26): C, 25.75; H, 4.32; S, 27.49. Found: C, 25.31; H, 3.94; S, 27.05.

Synthesis of <bold>CP9</bold>

This compound was prepared by refluxing a suspension of CuCN (179 mg, 2.0 mmol) during 3 h in MeCN in the presence of an excess of L2. Overall yield: 348 mg, 78%. IR (ATR): 2957 (m), 2911­(w), 2859 (w), 2810 (w), 2121 (s), 1442 (w), 1420 (w), 1407 (m), 1378 (w), 1272 (w), 1230 (w), 1180 (w), 1166 (m), 1119 (w), 1076 (w), 1057 (m), 1046 (w), 999 (w), 973 (w), 902 (m), 866 (w), 818 (w), 708 (m), 666 (m), 520 (w), 485 (w), 442 (w) cm–1. No satisfactory elemental analysis could be obtained for CP9.

Synthesis of <bold>CP10</bold>

L3 (0.3 mL, 1.7 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile, and an MeCN solution (25 mL) of CuI (226 mg, 1.2 mmol) was added dropwise. A white precipitate was observed within 5 min. The mixture was then stirred for 3 h to complete the reaction. The precipitate was filtered, washed with 2 × 10 mL of acetonitrile, and dried. CP10 was isolated as a white solid (173 mg, 46%). A small amount of this CP (20 mg) was dissolved in hot MeCN (10 mL). Overnight standing of the solution at 5 °C provided single-crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography. IR (ATR): 3100 (s), 2907 (m), 2863 (w), 1464 (m), 1416 (s), 1387­(w), 1367 (w), 1269 (w), 1237 (w), 1192 (s), 1167 (w), 1131 (w), 1104 (w),1056 (w), 1028 (w), 1005 (w), 946 (w), 907 (s), 881 (w), 819 (w), 744 (m), 655 (m), 623 (w), 501 (w), 467 (w), 421­(w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C16H32Cu3I3S4 (924.04): C, 20.80; H, 3.49; S, 13.88. Found: C, 20.45; H, 3.24; S, 13.47.

Synthesis of <bold>CP11</bold>

This material was prepared by following the same protocol by mixing L3 (0.3 mL, 1.7 mmol) and CuBr (175 mg, 1.2 mmol) providing CP11 as a white solid (103 mg, 27%). mp 152 °C; IR (ATR): 2955 (s), 2899 (m), 2868 (w), 1464 (m), 1416 (s), 1384 (w), 1366 (w), 1271 (w), 1236 (w), 1187(s), 1169 (w), 1131 (w), 1109 (w),1038 (w), 1005 (w), 947 (w), 908 (s), 889 (w), 871 (w), 828 (w), 817 (w), 764 (m), 677 (m), 661 (w), 637 (w), 463 (m) cm–1 Anal. Calcd for C16H32Cu2Br2S4 (639.59): C, 30.05; H, 5.04; S, 20.05. Found: C, 30.15; H, 4.84; S, 19.47.

Synthesis of <bold>CP12</bold>

This material was prepared by addition of CuCl (200 mg, 2.0 mmol) to a MeCN solution of 1.2 equiv of L3 providing CP12 as a pale yellow solid (369 mg, 67%). IR (ATR): 2956 (w), 2922 (w), 2899 (w), 2868 (w), 1489 (w), 1414 (m), 1253 (m), 1167­(m), 1129 (w), 1083 (w), 1037 (w), 999 (w), 905 (m), 880 (m), 841 (s), 758 (m), 731 (m), 639 (w), 474 (w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C16H32Cu2Cl2S4 (550.69): C, 34.90; H, 5.86; S, 23.29. Found: C, 32.90; H, 5.60; S, 21.91.

Synthesis of <bold>CP13</bold>

This CP was prepared by addition of neat L4 (2.0 mmol) to a MeCN solution of CuI (382 mg, 2.0 mmol), affording a white solid (458 mg, 80%). Mp: 221 °C. IR (ATR): 2953 (w), 2933 (w), 2909 (w), 2894 (w), 2854 (w), 1414 (w), 1251 (m), 1175 (w), 1089 (w), 999 (w), 902 (m), 881 (w), 843 (s), 759 (m), 728 (m), 638 (w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C7H16Cu2I2S2Si (573.32): C, 14.66; H, 2.81; S, 11.19. Found: C, 14.75; H, 2.54; S, 10.97.

Synthesis of <bold>CP15</bold>

This CP was obtained in a similar manner as a pale yellow solid (393 mg, 62%). IR (ATR): 2948 (w), 2921 (w), 2894 (w), 2857 (w), 1414 (w), 1253 (m), 1167 (w), 1083 (w), 998 (w), 904 (m), 881 (m), 840 (s), 757 (m), 731 (m), 639 (m), 574 (w), 474­(w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C7H16Cu2Cl2S2Si (390.42): C, 21.53; H, 4.13; S, 16.43. Found: C, 21.25; H, 3.98; S, 16.06.

Synthesis of <bold>CP16</bold>

This CP was obtained by dissolving CuI (191 mg, 1.0 mmol) in MeCN and subsequent addition of 1 equiv of neat L5 providing CP16 as a white solid (393 mg, 64%). IR (ATR): 2965 (w), 2915 (w), 2309 (w), 2275 (w), 1495 (w), 1453 (w), 1420 (m), 1366­(w), 1272 (w), 1224 (w), 1171 (w), 1072 (w), 1027 (w), 904 (w), 879 (w), 738 (m), 696 (s), 669 (m), 6451 (w), 589 (w), 497 (w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C14H18Cu2I2N2S2 (659.34): C, 25.50; H, 2.75; N, 4.25; S, 9.73. Found: C, 25.17; H, 2.25; N, 3.99; S, 10.10.

Synthesis of <bold>CP17</bold>

This CP was obtained by dissolving CuI (382 mg, 2.0 mmol) in warm EtCN followed by addition of neat L5 (196 mg, 1 mmol) and subsequent refluxing the white precipitate (520 mg, 90%). Mp: 237 °C. IR (ATR): 3055 (w), 3030 (w), 2967 (w), 2932 (w), 2902 (w), 1584 (w), 1494 (w), 1453 (w), 1407 (w), 1272 (w), 1222 (w), 1174 (w), 1157 (w), 1072 (w), 1030 (w), 1008 (w), 904 (w), 889 (w), 876 (w), 827 (w), 778 (w), 721 (m), 689 (s), 666 (w), 644 (m), 591 (w), 489 (w), 423 (w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C20H24Cu3I3S4 (964.03): C, 24.92; H, 2.50; S, 13.30. Found: C, 25.12; H, 2.27; S, 12.98.

This CP was obtained by dissolving CuBr (286 mg, 2.0 mmol) in MeCN and subsequent addition of neat L5 (196 mg, 1 mmol), affording a white precipitate. (400 mg, 83%). Mp: 186 °C. cln_elements.content: All compounds were found to be stable for several months under ambient atmosphere. The thermal properties of some selected CPs containing L2 (CP5, CP7, and CP8), L3 (CP10, CP11, and CP12) and ferrocenyl L6 ligands (CP19) were studied by TGA under air up to 850 °C. The first derivative plots of the TGA traces are given in the Supporting Information (Figures S37–S44) Temperatures of decomposition corresponding to a 5% loss of the total mass are given in . The thermogravimetric traces depicted in show that CPs containing L2 and L3 ligands present relatively identical thermal behavior. As already encountered for other thioether-based CPs, all thermal profiles of CPs containing bromide (CP7 and CP11) or chlorine (CP8) atoms present three main losses while the thermal decomposition of CP5 and CP10 containing iodide presents only two good decomposition steps. The first major weight loss can be attributed to the loss of ligands based on the comparison between the theoretical and experimental values (see ). The final residual contents values are also close to those calculated based on the formation of CuO. Comparison of the traces between CP7 and CP8 within the L2 series and between CP11 and CP12 within the L3 series indicates that, independent of the dimensionality (1D or 2D), a higher stability is always obtained for CP containing Cu2Br2 SBUs than those containing Cu2Cl2 rhomboids. This observation is consistent with our previous studies. It was however more difficult to obtain a tendency for CPs containing iodide. Compared to CP7 and CP8, the 1D CP5 that contains Cu2I2 rhomboids presents a lower thermal stability. Opposite to this, in the L3 series, the thermal stability of CP10 is higher than those of CP11 and CP12. In this case, the highest stability might be due to the presence of a Cu3I3 core. Comparison of thermal degradation temperatures between CP7 and CP11 containing Cu2Br2 rhomboids and between CP8 and CP12 containing Cu2Cl2 rhomboids indicates that L2 containing CPs (CP7 and CP8) are more stable than L3 containing materials (CP11 and CP12). One explanation that has already been suggested for this behavior is the difference in the boiling point value of the ligand. However, in our case, the boiling point of L3 (250 °C) is higher than that of L2 (224 °C). The dimer compound D1 presents the lowest stability with a first degradation step from 60 to 130 °C attributed to the loss of coordinated acetonitrile (). After that initial decomposition step, the thermal degradation profiles of D1 and CP19 look alike. The final residues might include both FeO and CuO as evidenced by a comparison between theoretical and experimental values.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties

All compounds were found to be stable for several months under ambient atmosphere. The thermal properties of some selected CPs containing L2 (CP5, CP7, and CP8), L3 (CP10, CP11, and CP12) and ferrocenyl L6 ligands (CP19) were studied by TGA under air up to 850 °C. The first derivative plots of the TGA traces are given in the Supporting Information (Figures S37-S44) Temperatures of decomposition corresponding to a 5% loss of the total mass are given in . The thermogravimetric traces depicted in  show that CPs containing L2 and L3 ligands present relatively identical thermal behavior. As already encountered for other thioether-based CPs, all thermal profiles of CPs containing bromide (CP7 and CP11) or chlorine (CP8) atoms present three main losses while the thermal decomposition of CP5 and CP10 containing iodide presents only two good decomposition steps. The first major weight loss can be attributed to the loss of ligands based on the comparison between the theoretical and experimental values (see ). The final residual contents values are also close to those calculated based on the formation of CuO. Comparison of the traces between CP7 and CP8 within the L2 series and between CP11 and CP12 within the L3 series indicates that, independent of the dimensionality (1D or 2D), a higher stability is always obtained for CP containing Cu2Br2 SBUs than those containing Cu2Cl2 rhomboids. This observation is consistent with our previous studies. It was however more difficult to obtain a tendency for CPs containing iodide. Compared to CP7 and CP8, the 1D CP5 that contains Cu2I2 rhomboids presents a lower thermal stability. Opposite to this, in the L3 series, the thermal stability of CP10 is higher than those of CP11 and CP12. In this case, the highest stability might be due to the presence of a Cu3I3 core. Comparison of thermal degradation temperatures between CP7 and CP11 containing Cu2Br2 rhomboids and between CP8 and CP12 containing Cu2Cl2 rhomboids indicates that L2 containing CPs (CP7 and CP8) are more stable than L3 containing materials (CP11 and CP12). One explanation that has already been suggested for this behavior is the difference in the boiling point value of the ligand. However, in our case, the boiling point of L3 (250 °C) is higher than that of L2 (224 °C). The dimer compound D1 presents the lowest stability with a first degradation step from 60 to 130 °C attributed to the loss of coordinated acetonitrile (). After that initial decomposition step, the thermal degradation profiles of D1 and CP19 look alike. The final residues might include both FeO and CuO as evidenced by a comparison between theoretical and experimental values.
